comment._content: I reckon from the tower of St Andrew's Church at Holborn Circus, see GoogleMapsSatellite . If you then go to the GoogleEarth plugin enable 3D and wiggle it around until you are on top of the church tower - aim SE towards St Pauls, and the Cathedral looks as in this photo. I can't think of any other buildings around at the time which might have been tall enough, unless it was another chimney. Chim chiminey, Chim chiminey, Chim chim cher-ee! A sweep is as lucky, As lucky can be ...

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content:
Well, as far as location goes I am pretty certain [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] is correct with the top of St Andrew's. The image has a rather odd feel to it - I initially thought it might be a composite as St Paul's seems rather dull compared with the more contrasty foreground buildings. And I'm still wondering what is going on with the further background - to the back left it looks like some larger buildings that are very out of proportion.

Anyway, I think the question raised over the Holborn viaduct is answered by the fact that the church is just south-east of Holborn Circus and as such it would be just out of shot to the left. In fact I suspect that what we can see coming into the shot from back-left is likely the back of where Newgate Street starts, at the end of what is now the viaduct. It also means that I don't *think* the tower of City Temple would be quite in shot either, if it were post 1874, so it's really hard to get any dating clues on this!

Out of interest, has anyone found the address and any dates for Stokes Leather Warehouse? I have tried a few simple searches but not come up with anything.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] It looks like the sky has been whited out (or whited in?). It was probably a dull grey. Hence the edges of the background skyline, and St. Paul's itself, looking all wrong.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a sister image pair(STP 0425) from the other side of St Pauls showing the Thames looking like silk rather than an open sewer, implying a long exposure - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/STP_0425/Image?lookfor=http://www... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Re 1869 Holborn Viaduct - the tall new buildings in this contemporary illustration would surely be seen in the photo if not the bridge ?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I found a T C Stokes ,described a s a leather cutter, who was declared bankrupt in October 1862, but delving in the London Gazette shows his address as 92 King St West, Hammersmith, so unlikely to have anything to do with this warehouse. In 1866, at the bankruptcy hearing of shoemakers WIlliam MacLennan and WIlliam Fryer, they stated "we got about five dozen kipps of leather from Stokes & Coy, shortly before our sequestration.The goods were nearly all cut up into Blucher boots." The partnership of Stokes and Company of Stafford went bankrupt was dissolved in 1865. They are described as "Tanners, Curriers, Leather Merchants, and Patent Leather Manufacturers". Perhaps they had a London warehouse? The OED defines a kipp or kip as 'The hide of a young or small beast (as a calf or lamb, or cattle of small breed), as used for leather.' or 'A set or bundle of such hides', and Blucher as 'A strong leather half-boot or high shoe, the actual pattern varying with the fashion', named after Field Marshal von Blücher.. Being at Waterloo and having a boot named after you, now where have I heard that one before.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Stokes and Company of Rugeley (Staffs) was a large firm, but no mention of a London warehouse History of Stokes and Comapny BTW Carol, I haven't found any relevant murders ..... yet.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Stokes Leather Warehouse visible in this 1867 Holborn Viaduct construction photo (far left, background) - collage.cityoflondon.gov.uk/collage/app?service=external/...

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] excellent, so we have a 'latest' date of 1887 (or possibly even 1879)

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Bingo! I had seen that image, but couldn't work it out. But prompted by you I've had a closer look - the church in that image is The Church of the Holy Sepulchre (Musicians' Church) along Newgate St. This thoroughly confused me until I realised that the caption on that image is incorrect - Stokes LEather Warehouse is *far-right* - it's the building propped up, and comparing it with this iamge you can see the same architectural details. So that means the buildings to the left of it (as we look at the image) were knocked down when they built the viaduct, dating this to no later than ca 1865 (assuming they would have to knock them down fairly near the start of the building works, which lasted from 1863-69).

So I now realise that what I thought was the back of the properties on the south side of Newgate St are actually the fronts of the north side, and the intersection of Holborn/Newgate St and Farringdon St is just off by no more than a few metres to the left of the image.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I also should have added, full credit to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] for his original thoughts on the viewpoint, direction and suggestion of such an early date. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Carol, any chance you could post the full stereoview? I could then 'wiggle' it!
